Introduction to DVD and Blu-ray Versions of the Films

The official website for the DVD and Blu-ray version releases is Warner Home Video. While this site gives summary information on the various editions available – Regular, Blu-ray, Ultimate, Box Sets, Gift Sets – probably IMDB is the best source of information on various edition release dates for the films on DVD alone – widescreen, full screen, box sets, and gift sets. So many DVD editions/releases have appeared over the years for the same film that it gets very convoluted. Go to the movie page for the specific film you are interested in, and at the very bottom of the page you’ll find a link called “dvd details” in the section called “Related Products.” Then you can select the particular edition you’re interested in from the pull-down menu, and it will generally give both the edition name and release date.

The Blu-ray website is far better if you want to find specific details on the special features of each film quickly. Search for “Harry Potter” and you’ll get a listing of all Blu-ray versions available: Regular, Ultimate, Box Sets. Then, each individual film offers such details as:

A good source for content lists of special features is the Blu-ray site. Check out the Blu-ray “News” section, and the individual film edition pages.

Other Versions of the Films: VHS, VCD, HD, and UMD

[Images forthcoming.]

Introducing the Changes in Media Systems

We have been in a media transition for decades into increasingly digital modes of delivery as the standard. (For some background history on this topic, check out the Wikipedia article on DVD.)

With sound, this has progressed from vinyl records and reel-to-reel; to eight-track; to cassette tape; to standard CD (compact disc); to enhanced CD/CD-ROM with additional content features and items (like posters, links to websites video clips); to DVD (digital videodisc) and digital editions that greatly expand on the capability of the media, the quality of the sound and mix, and delivery system options (computer, Walkman, iPod, etc )..

With video, this journey has included the fight between the higher-quality Beta format versus the more popular VHS (Video Home System) format – with VHS the winner; to the laserdisc that was the size of a vinyl record; to DVD; to the fight between HD (High Definition) and Blu-ray formats for enhanced quality of picture and sound; to various forms of digital copies that allow for playing of standard definition or high definition video on various delivery systems from personal computers to smart phones to videogame systems.

Along the way, VCD (Video Compact Disc) has always been a lesser-known but ever-present cousin to the standard video delivery systems available. VCD typically seems more prominent where personal computers are more common than expensive high-definition and digital equipment. The compact disc capacity being so much less than what’s on a DVD, this meant that a movie that would fit on one DVD usually is split across three VCDs. The smaller capacity also meant few add-on features would fit. So, usually a VCD set has perhaps a movie trailer or two, plus maybe a few featurettes.

Harry Potter Movies on Obsolete and Obscure Media

In my research to put together the pages on DVD/Blu-ray, I did what I could to figure out how some of the other types of media were used and then discarded over the years. Here’s what I’ve been able to find out so far.

VHS Cassettes. The VHS format was still in wide use during the early part of the 2000 decade. So, VHS editions of the first three movies were produced: Sorcerer’s/Philosopher’s Stone (VHS released in 2002), Chamber of Secrets (2003), and Prisoner of Azkaban (2004). The most common versions on eBay and Amazon are English, Spanish, and French – along with the less-frequently-found UK PAL format editions. VHS versions of For Your Consideration “Awards Screeners” were also available for at least the first two films, to promote the movies to those in various professional fields who would be voting on Academy Awards and the like.

VCD Sets. VCDs are generally found outside North America, most often in Asian markets, and secondarily in Europe and the Middle-East. So, details are harder to figure out. But I have acquired a VCD set for Chamber of Secrets, so I’m assuming VCDs were also produced for at least Sorcerer’s/Philosopher’s Stone. This particular set is bilingual English/Cantonese with Chinese subtitles. In my searches on eBay, I’ve also run across a set of four promotional postcards from Singapore with the slogan, “Own the magic on DVD and VCD!”

HD Discs. There were HD editions produced for only the first five films, and in 2007, the Years 1-5 Gift Set was produced with an HD option as well as in standard definition DVD and high definition Blu-ray. All five were produced as single-disc HD editions, with Order of the Phoenix also issued as a”Combo Pack” of HD plus DVD. HD editions are distinguished by a deep burgundy plastic “clamshell” cases, just as Blu-ray cases are distinguished by that specific color of medium blue and regular DVDs usually by black or white.

UMD Discs. All eight Harry Potter films are available in UMD editions for the PSP PlayStation Portable system. UMD reputedly has similar quality of at least standard DVD.

To my knowledge, no Harry Potter films were ever produced on Beta cassette or laserdisc; those formats had already passed from the scene.

Blu-ray Description

From J.K. Rowling’s delightful bestseller, Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone is sheer screen enchantment. At its center is Harry, orphaned, unloved, rescued, enrolled as a wizard-in-training at Hogwarts Academy and as his telltale forehead scar shows, destined for great things. Experience the rich characters, lavish surroundings, wizardly tools and customs, the high-flying sport of Quidditch … and more beyond imagining. For the most magic ever to visit your house, see you on Platform 9-3/4!

Look back on an amazing decade’s worth of movies with Daniel, Rupert and Emma in new and vintage interviews never seen before.

Plus: Exclusive introduction by Daniel Radcliffe.

Widescreen DVD and Blu-ray Description

Cars fly, trees fight back and a mysterious elf comes to warn Harry Potter at the start of the second year of his amazing journey into the world of wizardry. This year at Hogwarts, spiders talk, letters scold and Harry’s own unsettling ability to speak to snakes turns his friends against him. From dueling clubs to rogue Bludgers, it’s a year of adventure and danger when bloody writing on a wall announces: The Chamber of Secrets has been opened. To save Hogwarts will require all of Harry, Ron and Hermione’s magical abilities and courage in this spellbinding adaptation of J.K. Rowling’s second book. Get ready to be amused and petrified as Harry Potter shows he’s more than a wizard, he’s a hero!

Blu-ray Description

Year Three at Hogwarts means new fun and challenges as Harry learns how to approach a Hippogriff, transform shape-shifting Boggarts into hilarity and even turn back time. But the term also brings danger. Soul-sucking Dementors hover over the school. An ally of the accursed He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named lurks within the castle walls. Fearsome wizard Sirius Black escapes Azkaban. And Harry will confront them all. Directed by Alfonso Cuaron and based on J.K. Rowling’s third book, this wondrous spellbinder soars with laughs, shivers and the unique breathless surprise of a Harry Potter adventure. Mischief managed!

Widescreen DVD and Blu-ray Description

When Harry Potter’s name emerges from the Goblet of Fire, he becomes a competitor in a grueling battle for glory among three wizarding schools – the Triwizard Tournament. But since Harry never submitted his name for the Tournament, who did? Now Harry must confront a deadly dragon, fierce water demons and an enchanted maze only to find himself in the cruel grasp of He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named. In this fourth film adaptation of J.K. Rowling’s Harry Potter series, everything changes as Harry, Ron and Hermione leave childhood forever and take on challenges greater than anything they could have imagined.

Plunge into the fun as Daniel gets the sound of underwater dialogue just right.

Feel the magic as music is added to a scene, intensifying the action and guiding the story.

DVD-ROM PC Enhanced Features

There was an exclusive bonus disc available only from Target. It had one additional special feature on it: Building the Magic: The Sets of Harry Potter. This feature is available on the Ultimate Edition, so don’t worry too much if you aren’t able to find this disc on eBay or elsewhere.

For Order of the Phoenix, there was an exclusive 2-disc Deluxe Set with an additional third disc featuring, “Building the Magic: The Sets of Harry Potter.” It was only available from Target. Their edition included a lenticular slip cover that alternated between two halves of a battle scene: Voldemort and his followers facing right, and Harry and students of the Order of the Phoenix facing left. I don’t have the slip cover, unfortunately, but you can view it here on the Amazon site.

Widescreen DVD and Blu-ray Description

The rebellion begins! Lord Voldemort has returned, but he Ministry of Magic is doing everything it can to keep the wizarding world from knowing the truth – including appo9inting Ministry official Dolores Umbridge as the new Defense Against the Dark Arts professor at Hogwarts. When Umbridge refuses to teach practical defensive magic, Ron and Hermione convince Harry to secretly train a select group of students for the wizarding war that lies ahead. A terrifying showdown between good and evil awaits in this enthralling film version of the fifth novel in J.K. Rowling’s Harry Potter series. Prepare for battle!

Ultimate Edition Description (Blu-ray)

Ultimate Edition, Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, including over one hour of never-before-seen bonus content.

Creating the World of Harry Potter, Part 5: Evolution. Deeper. Bolder. Darker. As the eight Harry Potter films trace Harry’s journey from innocent schoolboy to selfless hero, the series undergoes a transformation. Widescreen DVD Description

As Lord Voldemort tightens his grip on both the Muggle and wizarding worlds, Hogwarts is no longer a safe haven. Harry suspects perils may even lie within the castle, but Dumbledore is more intent upon preparing him for the final battle fast approaching. Together they work to find the key to unlock Voldemort’s defenses and to this end. Dumbledore recruits his old friend and colleague Horace Slughorn, who he believes holds crucial information. Even as the decisive showdown looms, romance blossoms for Harry, Ron, Hermione and their classmates. Love is in the air, but danger lies ahead and Hogwarts may never be the same again.

Ultimate Edition Description (Blu-ray)

Ultimate Edition, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, including over one hour of never-before-seen bonus content.

Creating the World of Harry Potter, Part 6: Magical Effects. In Harry Potter’s world, portraits come to life, potions transform, time reverses, Quidditch players soar, dragons attack and magic is everywhere. Now, fascinating new insights, interviews and watch-it-happen footage let you experience the triumphs of technical wizards who conjured up an awe-inspiring alternate reality.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1

Widescreen DVD Description

Harry, Ron and Hermione set out on their perilous mission to track down and destroy the secret to Voldemort’s immortality and destruction – the Horcruxes. On their own and on the run, the three friends must now rely on one another more than ever … but Dark Forces in their midst threaten to tear them apart. Meanwhile, the wizarding world has become a dangerous place. The long-feared war has begun and the Dark Lord has seized control of the Ministry of Magic and even Hogwarts, terrorizing and arresting all who might oppose him. The Chosen One has become the hunted one as the Death Eaters search for Harry with orders to bring him to Voldemort … alive.

Blu-ray Slipcover Description
